SystemOutput:
CC:

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HPI:

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, presenting today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts, tired, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He has been experiencing bloating and shortness of breath during exertion. He has had a slight cough and occasional chest cramps. He has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and reports it has been stable. His diet has been off due to recent home renovations.

PMH:

1. Congestive heart failure
2. Hypertension

MEDICATIONS:

1. Lasix
2. Lisinopril 20 mg daily

EXAM:

Vital signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.

Physical examination:
- Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters
- Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
- Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
- Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS:

Chest x-ray: Fluid in lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation

ASSESSMENT:

1. Congestive heart failure: Fluid retention
2. Hypertension: Well-managed

PLAN:

1. Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day
2. Weigh daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms
3. Order another echocardiogram
4. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily
5. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations via patient portal
6. Follow up after test results are received

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after she was rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident. She has no other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation

EXAM

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit shows a comminuted distal phalanx fracture.

IMPRESSION

Right middle finger distal phalanx fracture.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain, dispense 8. She is provided a finger splint and will return in 2 weeks for a follow-up x-ray. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports that he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. He heard a pop and experienced pain in his lower back. The incident occurred on Saturday morning, and the patient has had stiffness in his back since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat for pain relief, but they have not been very effective. The patient experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain and stiffness.
• Neurological: Reports tingling in toes on the right foot, which has resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Back x-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain.
   • Medical Reasoning: Lumbar strain from lifting heavy boxes.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2.
   • Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.
   • Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is monitoring his knee and managing symptoms.
   • Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Roger is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up for chest pain. The patient was doing yard work over the weekend when he began to feel short of breath and chest pain for approximately an hour. He denies a history of chest pain. The patient notes that after he finished, he felt fine. He has not had any other symptoms since that time. He denies a family history of heart disease.

The patient underwent right knee surgery a couple of months ago and has been feeling well since then. He has been in rehab and recovery. He denies chest pain while doing exercises in physical therapy for his knee.

His blood pressure was noted to be 180/95 mmHg when he visited the emergency room. He notes that his blood pressure has not been as high as usual.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Neck
• General Examination: I do feel a little enlarged thyroid that is not tender. She has a carotid bruit on the right side.

Respiratory
• Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, but I do hear a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Gastrointestinal
• Examination of Abdomen: Soft. There is a healed scar on the right knee from prior knee surgery.

Musculoskeletal
• Examination: There is no lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Blood pressure is elevated.

EKG is normal.

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up. He presented to the emergency room for chest pain and elevated blood pressure of 180/95. His EKG from the emergency room was normal, but ejection fraction on echocardiogram was abnormal. His blood pressure today was still elevated.

Chest pain and hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Given his recent episode of blood pressure elevation and chest pain, I suspect an element of coronary artery disease as well as pumping dysfunction.
• Medical Treatment: We will change his blood pressure regimen to carvedilol 25 mg twice a day. He should also continue lisinopril 10 mg a day and I want to see how his blood pressure does on that regimen. I also recommended cardiac catheterization on him to make sure that he does not have any blockages in his heart.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her finger strap got caught and bent her finger back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management, but the pain persists. The patient experiences pain with movement of the finger.

Ms. Brooks also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She had her appendix removed at the age of 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.
• X-ray: No fractures observed, everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right index finger pain following a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's x-ray shows no fractures, and the physical examination indicates tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint.
• Medical Treatment: Provide an aluminum foam splint for the finger. Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient should return for a follow-up visit.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and increased anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, feverishness, chills.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Increased anxiety and depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Iron deficiency anemia
• Hysterectomy in 1996

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily
• Over-the-counter vitamin B12

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Normal breath sounds.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Iron deficiency anemia:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia and is currently experiencing symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and headaches.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after the upper endoscopy and colonoscopy. She will also schedule an appointment with the hematologist. The patient is advised to take her iron pills with orange juice for better absorption and to continue this for 8-12 weeks before reassessing her blood work.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents for consultation due to a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient has been experiencing worsening headaches over the past few months, which led to an MRI and serology workup. The MRI revealed a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient also reports bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, rash, or neck stiffness. Positive for fatigue.
• Neurological: Positive for headaches, lightheadedness, and dizziness. Denies numbness, tingling, or passing out.
• Ophthalmologic: Denies vision changes. Last eye check in the fall.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Unremarkable. No known medical problems or medications.

FAMILY HISTORY

• Unknown, as the patient was adopted.

SOCIAL HISTORY

• Occupation: Computer programmer.
• Marital status: Married for 25 years.
• Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Cranial nerve examination: Grossly intact.
• Motor and sensory examination: No focal deficits in upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic examination: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. Ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Ward is a 52-year-old male with a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion, likely a benign pituitary adenoma. The patient is experiencing headaches and bitemporal hemianopia due to optic chiasmal compression.

• Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and MRI findings are consistent with a pituitary adenoma causing optic chiasmal compression.
• Medical Treatment: Surgical intervention is indicated to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. The patient will be scheduled for a transsphenoidal approach surgery. A referral to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test will be made to monitor vision changes before and after surgery.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She presents with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved after the ER visit. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during that time, which has also resolved. The patient mentions that she was going through a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Endorses chest pain and difficulty swallowing in the past, resolved. Denies abdominal pain.
• Cardiovascular: Denies any current chest pain.
• Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

ASSESSMENT

The patient is a female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing, which have resolved since the initial episode three months ago. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
2. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day, normal fluid intake.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with her syndrome, we will obtain a screening kidney ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Diana is a pleasant patient who presents today with a right wrist injury sustained during a fall while carrying laundry down the stairs. She reports immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist following the fall. She has tried ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal improvement. The patient denies any history of diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis. She reports no numbness or tingling in her fingers but has difficulty making a tight fist due to pain.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Not provided.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right wrist pain.
• Neurological: Slightly diminished sensation to light touch over the right wrist.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
Pleasant, cooperative female in no apparent distress.

Neurological
Grossly intact. Slightly diminished sensation to light touch over the right wrist.

Cardiovascular
Regular rate and rhythm.

Musculoskeletal
Exam of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Bony crepitus noted. Metacarpals intact.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture with extra-articular involvement and dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. Ulnar styloid fracture is present.

ASSESSMENT

• Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

Ms. Diana presents with a right wrist injury sustained during a fall. The findings of her examination and x-ray are consistent with a Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

The patient and I discussed her history, symptoms, and radiographic findings. We discussed the treatment options, including conservative management with bracing and surgical intervention. The patient elected to proceed with surgery. In the meantime, she will be provided with a brace for her right wrist and pain medication (50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours). Post-surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

Proceed with surgery as planned. Wear the brace as instructed. Attend physical therapy as prescribed. Follow up in one month for reassessment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 57-year-old male who presents with right knee pain following a fall on his property one week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has been experiencing pain with flexion and extension of the knee. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling. He rates his pain as 4/10 when moving the knee. 

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Not reported.
Smoking status: Not reported.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with pain to palpation on the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion. No pain on the lateral aspect of the knee.

RESULTS

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Recommend a knee brace for support and healing. Advise the patient to ice the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. Encourage elevation and rest of the affected leg.

2. Hypertension: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg. Refer the patient to nutrition counseling to improve dietary habits and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

3. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment to monitor the patient's knee pain and hypertension management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Wayne is a patient who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He cannot recall any specific injury but has been active and working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the shoulder before, but nothing that Tylenol could not alleviate. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which helps to take the edge off but does not completely relieve the pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left shoulder pain and limited range of motion. No numbness or tingling in arms or hands.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Limited active and passive range of motion in the left shoulder. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill less than three seconds in the left arm. Sensation is intact to light touch.

VITALS REVIEWED

• All vitals within normal limits.

RESULTS

Left shoulder x-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Wayne presents with left shoulder pain, most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

• Medical Reasoning: The patient has limited range of motion and tenderness in the left shoulder, with no fractures seen on x-ray.
• Additional Testing: I have ordered an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the issue.
• Medical Treatment: Refer the patient to physical therapy for six to eight weeks. Continue taking Tylenol for pain management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: If symptoms do not improve, we can consider a steroid injection for the shoulder to provide relief.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain. She reports that the pain occurs less than once a day while walking, and her knee suddenly feels like it will give out. The pain passes quickly, and she has not experienced any popping or injury to the knee. The pain has not been severe enough to require pain medication. Andrea is concerned about an upcoming trip that will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and she is unsure if her knee will be able to handle the activities.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Patient is on medication for hypertension.
• Endocrine: Patient has diabetes and is on metformin.
• Musculoskeletal: Patient experiences occasional left knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
• Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam shows no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspect arthritis. Plan to prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus: Order a Hemoglobin A1c to assess the need for adjustments to Metformin dosage. Also, order a lipid panel.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Recent diagnosis of stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer, follow-up during neo adjuvant chemotherapy.

HPI:

Beverly is a 53-year-old female who presents today for follow-up during her neo adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending. She reports a minimal cough, sore throat, and mild fatigue. No nausea or vomiting. No shortness of breath. She has good support from nursing staff, family, and friends.

EXAM:

Vitals: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits.
Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, possibly related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS:

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

IMPRESSION:

1. Stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer.
2. Radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN:

1. Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion and consider surgical removal if the tumor has shrunk sufficiently.
2. Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days to reduce inflammation from radiation pneumonitis.
3. Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow for painful swallowing, to be used four times a day.

All questions were answered. Follow-up at the next scheduled visit.

CC:

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level

HPI:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of low IgA level found during a recent physical examination. She reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual. She denies any frequent abdominal infections or diarrhea. She was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on Metformin.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Metformin
Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Type 2 Diabetes
Atrial Fibrillation

FAMILY HISTORY:

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

EXAM:

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.

LABS:

IgA level: Low (consistent with IgA deficiency)

ASSESSMENT:

IgA deficiency - common immunodeficiency with low likelihood of other immunodeficiencies in this case.

PLAN:

1. Order additional blood work to check other antibody levels.
2. Educate patient on potential risks and signs of infections to watch for.
3. Advise patient to inform healthcare providers of IgA deficiency if needing blood products in the future.
4. Follow up after lab results are available to discuss any further management needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Lawrence is a patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery work during the pandemic and started to develop elbow pain about four days ago. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain and tenderness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vitals: Stable and within normal limits.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation and moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm and resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow showed no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advised the patient to rest the elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. Instructed the patient to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
• Follow-up: Scheduled a follow-up appointment in one week to assess the patient's progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling.

HPI:

David is a patient who presents today after a recent visit to the emergency department due to chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling. He reports falling down while walking outside and experiencing chest pain, which he initially attributed to heartburn. He admits to not consistently taking his prescribed medications and not following a strict diet.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Bumex, Cozaar, Norvasc

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Hypertension

EXAM:

Blood pressure: 128/72
Neck: No jugular venous distention
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable
Lungs: Clear bilaterally
Lower extremities: Trace edema

RESULTS:

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

IMPRESSION:

Congestive heart failure likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.

PLAN:

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
2. Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily.
3. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
4. Consult with nutritionist for dietary advice.
5. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
6. Obtain a home scale and monitor weight daily; call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
7. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
8. Follow up in 2 weeks to assess progress and review test results.

All questions were answered, and the patient was advised to take medications consistently and follow a strict diet.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain in the right side of the abdomen below the ribs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a male patient who presents with sharp pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when present. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PAST HISTORY

Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdominal exam: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS
Imaging

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer to collect the stone for analysis.
4. Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and discuss further treatment options, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy, if necessary.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Increase fluid intake, use prescribed pain medication as needed, strain urine to collect stone, and contact the clinic if symptoms worsen. Attend follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, presenting with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. The ulcer began as a blister approximately six weeks ago after wearing tight shoes. The patient noticed a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. The patient's primary care doctor started him on antibiotics six days ago. The patient reports fever, chills, and worsening pain in the foot. The wound has turned black around the edges, and the patient is experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. The patient also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient has been coughing and experiencing shortness of breath for the last two days.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes, diabetic neuropathy, well-controlled with an A1c of 6.7.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Coughing and shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain in the right foot and calf muscle.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No pain on palpation of the affected area.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, presenting with a non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot.

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, and the wound is not healing despite antibiotic therapy.
   • Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   • Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, obtain a culture, and consider changing antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
   • Follow-up: Monitor the patient closely and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher recently, and it is important to maintain good glycemic control to promote wound healing.
   • Specialist Referrals: Follow up with the patient's endocrinologist to ensure continued management of diabetes and maintenance of A1c below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee tick bite and pain.

HPI:

Richard is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. He reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. The tick bite occurred over a week ago and has been causing burning pain. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, and difficulty moving his knee. He has not experienced a tick bite or been diagnosed with Lyme disease before. He reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Lisinopril 20 mg daily
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Hypertension
Diabetes

EXAM:

Vital signs: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4°F
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Right knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion, bull's-eye rash present

ASSESSMENT:

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease
2. Hypertension
3. Diabetes

PLAN:

1. Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks for possible Lyme disease
2. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests
3. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension
4. Order lipid panel for cholesterol monitoring
5. Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes
6. Order hemoglobin A1C to assess blood sugar control
7. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function
8. Follow up in 3 weeks to assess response to treatment and review lab results
